Table 1 Pd-catalyzed tandem reaction of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine and MeOH under different conditions a . a Phenylacetylene 5 mmol, cyclohexylamine 6 mmol, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 0.1 mmol (2 mol%), Ligand 0.1 mmol (2 mol%), P/Pd = 4, additive 0.5 mmol (10 mol%), CO 3 MPa, time 24 h, temp. 120 ℃, MeOH as solvent (3 mL). b Determined by GC analysis with internal standard (n-dodecane) method. Table 2 The generality of L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system for tandem reaction of alkynes with CO and aliphatic amines in MeOH a . a Alkynes 3 mmol, amines 3.6 mmol, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 0.1 mmol (2 mol%), L1 0.1 mmol (2 mol%),, PTSA H2O 0.5 mmol (10 mol%), MeOH 3 mL, CO 3 MPa, time 24 h, temp. 120 ℃. Yields were reported as the isolated yields. The isolated products were characterized by 1H/13C NMR spectra (see SI). Graphical abstract One-pot three-step tandem reaction via aminocarbonylation-methoxycarbonylation-cyclization sequence for synthesis of N-substituted succinimides. A series of base-built-in-PNP-ligands (L1-L4) were synthesized and fully characterized. The synthesis methodology for these ligands were simple and efficient without involvement of high-risky BuLi or high-cost transition metal catalysts. With the aid of the pyrazinyl-tertiary amine-based bis-PNP ligand of L1, in the coexistence of the nucleophiles of amine and MeOH, the terminal alkynes smoothly converted to N-substituted succinimides in moderate to excellent isolated yields, via one-pot three-step tandem reaction in aminocarbonylation-methoxycarbnylation-cyclization sequence. The developed L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalyst exhibited typical cascade catalysis with divergent performance towards each individual reaction-step. And the second-step methoxycarbonylation of the branched α,β-unsaturated amides towards ω-amido esters was a decent detour for the successful production of N-substituted succinimides from alkynes, CO and primary amines. Keywords Base-built-in ligands Cascade catalysis Carbonylation Aminocarbonylation Methoxycarbonylation Ammonolysis Succinimides Tandem reaction Data availability I have shared the link to my data at the Attach File step. 1 Introduction N-substituted succinimides as a subclass of cyclic imides are important compounds that have numerous applications in chemistry, biology, and material science [1–3] due to the prevalence of the succinimide moiety in nature [4–6]. For example, N-substituted succinimides derivatives are valuable structural motifs for a wide range of pharmaceuticals and biologically active molecules [7–9], as defined as Phensuximide [10–12], Methsuximide [13], Palasimide [14–16], and Moiramide [17] (Scheme 1 a). They also have potential applications in material science and serve as useful synthetic intermediates for the construction of important heterocyclic frameworks such as pyrrolidines and γ-lactams [18–20]. In addition, they are useful building blocks in the aerospace industry, natural rubber due to the strong electron-withdrawing-imide groups [21]. Due to their wide range of applications, many methods have been reported for the synthesis of N-substituted succinimides. Traditionally, succinimides can be prepared by cyclization of succinic acids or succinic anhydride with ammonia or amines [22–27]. And N-substituted succinimides can be derived from 1,4-conjugate addition of maleimide with arylboronic acids [28–31], or transition metal-catalyzed oxidative carbonylation of amides [32–35]. However, these approaches generally require expensive feedstocks and/or hazardous oxidant alongside the production of many byproducts. As a high atom-economical reaction, transition metal-catalyzed carbonylation of alkynes provided a straightforward method for the synthesis of succinimide and its N-substituted derivatives [36–39]. To date, several transition metal catalysts such as Fe [40–42] and Pd [43,44] have been developed for the synthesis of N-substituted succinimides via carbonylation of alkynes with amines (Scheme 1b). It has been indicated that with the developed Fe-catalytic systems [40–42], only one-step reaction happened to furnish the formation of N-substituted succinimides. In contrast, with Pd-catalytic systems [43,44], the one-pot two-step bis-aminocarbonylation happened, wherein alkyne is firstly converted to α,β-unsaturated amide, and then the formed α,β-unsaturated amide with gem-positioned C=C double bond continues to transform into succinimides upon CO-insertion and intramolecular ammonolysis. Inspiringly, in 2010, E. Ali reported a Pd-catalyzed methoxycarbonylation of gem-positioned α,β-unsaturated amides for the synthesis of ω-amido esters and then N-substituted succinimides via the ensued intramolecular ammonolysis of ω-amido esters [45]. On the other hand, we also have reported an interesting methoxycarbolynation-ammonolysis tandem reaction for synthesis of amides from olefins [46,47]. It means that methoxycarbonylation process of unsaturated compounds (olefins/alkynes) may serve as a detour for the synthesis of amides upon ammonolysis of the resultant esters by amines, especially for the unworkable aminocarbonylation of α,β-unsaturated amides with alkaline aliphatic amines [48–51]. Different from the previously reported methodologies via one-step or two-step reaction suffering from the low selectivity as well as the amine-substrate limitation [44], herein for the first time we unveiled a new one-pot three-step synthesis protocol via aminocarbonylation-methoxycarbonylation-cyclization tandem reaction for the production of N-substituted succinimides with excellent selectivity and wide amine-substrate applicability (Schem1-c). It was found that, L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system exerted mono-metal (Pd) cascade catalysis with divergent selectivity to each separate reaction step. Therein, the methoxycarbonylation of branched α,β-unsaturated amide towards ω-amido ester was a decent detour to guarantee the successful formation of N-substituted succinimides. In order to elucidate the structure/composition-activity correlation, besides of L1, the other ligands of L2-L4 were synthesized in parallel since the catalytic performance of the required Pd-catalysts in terms of activity, chemo/regio-selectivity and stability was highly dependent on the of the involved ligands [52–55]. As for L1-L3, the two flexible PNP-units with potential P,P-chelation effect were introduced at the para-position of pyrazinyl, or para-/ortho- position of terphenyl respectively. In comparison, L4 only possessing two bis-NP-units was prepared while the center phenyl-ring was replaced by pyrazinyl-ring. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization First, L1-L4 containing flexible PNP-unit or PN-unit as a type of base-built-in ligands were synthesized in high yields by taking advantage of Mannich condensation of aniline, formaldehyde and diphenylphosphine (HPPh2) as described in the Experimental Section. This synthesis method avoids the use of oxygen/air-sensitive and dangerous BuLi as well as the transition metal catalyst. As shown in Fig. 1 , each of L1-L4 corresponds to a singlet P-signal due to the highly symmetrical structure, which appears at quite higher field (δ, −18 ∼ -27 ppm) with indication of electron-rich nature of these as-synthesized ligands. Compared to the terphenyl-based ligand of L2 (δ, −27.75 ppm) or L3 (δ, −27.71 ppm), the pyrazinyl-centred ligand of L1 (δ, −18.77 ppm) or L4 (δ, −24.36 ppm) becomes more electron-deficient due to the increased p-π-conjugated effect. Reasonably, the increased p-π-conjugated effect from 2,5-diphenylpyrazinyl-unit also made the second-step Mannich condensation difficult. As a result, only one PPh2-fragment is located at N-site as observed in L4 in comparison to L2. The molecular structures of L1 and L3 determined by the single crystals X-ray diffraction are presented in Fig. 2 . It is demonstrated that, as for L1 and L3, the P⋅⋅⋅P distance in each PNP-unit is ca. 5.0 ∼ 5.2 Å [L1: P1⋅⋅P2 5.1968(7) Å; L3, P1⋅⋅P2 5.0467(2) Å], which is potential to develop PP-chelation to Pd-center in cis-position by taking advantage of the flexibility of the neighbored rotatory methylene-units as well as the stabilization of the six-member-ring structure as observed before [56]. In addition, as for L1, the hemilabile P,N-chelation (P1…N2 distance, 3.39 Å) to Pd-center to develop an energy-favored six-member ring structure was also available, which will further facilitate the stability of the Pd-complex (catalyst). In comparison, L3 with terphenyl-unit was in a lack of such P,N-chelating effect. 2.2 Tandem reaction of alkynes with CO and amine/MeOH for synthesis for N-alkyl succinimide with ligand-modified Pd-catalyst Initially, the reaction of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine and CO in MeOH was selected as a model reaction to optimize the reaction conditions (provided in Table S1 of SI). Under the optimal conditions [Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 as precursor (2 mol%), PTSA H2O as additive, L1/Pd = 1/1 M ratio, PTSA H2O/Pd = 5/1 M ratio, PCO 3 MPa, 120 °C, 24 h, and MeOH as solvent], the reaction was performed. It was indicated that, with presence of L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system and coexistence of the nucleophiles of cyclohexylamine and MeOH, the target 3-phenyl-N-cyclohexyl-succinimide of 3ab was obtained in GC yield of 89 % (Entry 1). Besides of 3ab, the side-products of 3a (branched α,β-unsaturated amide) and 3b (ω-amido ester) were found concurrently (3a/3b/3ab=/5/91) (Entry 1). However, without the presence of MeOH, only branched 3a was obtained with 100 % regio-selectivity via one-step aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine (Entry 2). Similarly, when MeOH was replaced by toluene (NMP or MeCN), only the formation of 3a was observed under the same applied conditions (Entries 3–5). These results revealed that MeOH-involved methoxycarbonylation of 3a towards 3b (rather than the aminocarbonylation of 3a towards 3c) was a must-required pathway for formation of 3ab upon cyclization (intramolecular ammonolysis) of 3b. In contrast, under the same conditions, with L2 (or L3) instead of L1 to repeat the reaction, the selectivity of 3ab was decreased to some extent, affording 3ab in the yield of 61 % (or 65 %) (Entries 6 and 7). However, when L4 without PNP-fragment in the structure was applied instead of L1, no 3ab was formed at all but only 3a was obtained with 100 % regio-selectivity, which means that only the aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine (towards 3a) happed even with the presence of MeOH and the following reactions were completely prohibited. Evidently, the target 3ab along with the ω-amido ester of 3b was found universally with L1-L3 whereas with L4, only 3a was observed (Entries 1, 6 and 7 vs 8), implying the requisite of PNP-unit with PP-chelating effect in the ligand structures. On the other hand, the additional incorporation of the pyrazinyl-base-unit in place of terphenyl made the resultant ligand of L1 more effective to promote the transformation rate from 3a towards 3b and then 3b towards 3ab. It was also noted that in comparison to the precursors of Pd(PPh3)4, Pd(OAc)2, and PdI2, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 was proved to be the best choice (Entries 1 vs 9–11), suggesting the requirement of Cl--counter-anion with small size and strong coordination ability. Without exception, the presence of acid-additive was necessarily required and PTSA⋅H2O was the best one for this three-step tandem reaction (Entry 1 vs 12–15). It was noted that, although MeOH coexisted with cyclohexylamine, the intermediate product of α,β-unsaturated ester 3a’ (derived from the methoxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene) was not observed at all. However, when the reaction time was reduced to 4 h, 3a’ was universally found from room temperature (RT) to 100 °C (See Fig. S1 in SI). But at 120 °C in 4 h, 3a’ was not observed anymore instead with the formation of 3a and 3b. These results indicated that, in co-existence of MeOH and cyclohexylamine, the methoxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene indeed happed under very mild conditions to afford the α,β-unsaturated ester of 3a’, which could be ammonolyzed by cyclohexylamine at the higher temperature (120 °C) to give the α,β-unsaturated amide of 3a due to the more thermodynamically stability of the amide compound than the corresponding ester. Hence, as observed in Table 1 , only the α,β-unsaturated amide of 3a was observed at the reaction temperature at 120 °C. The kinetic evolution profile of the tandem reaction of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine in MeOH over L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 system further disclosed the three-step reaction sequence. As clearly indicated in Fig. 3 , initially, the α,β-unsaturated amide of 3a was produced upon aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine, which reached its maximum amount in 4 h. Later on, the formed 3a began to be consumed gradually, along with the generation of the ω-amido ester of 3b upon methoxycatbonylation of 3a with CO and MeOH, which reached its maximum amount in 12 h. Afterwards, the generation of 3ab became prevailing until 3a and 3b were nearly depleted in 28 h. Apparently, 3a and 3b were the intermediate products for the synthesis of succinimide of 3ab. And with the same L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system, the reaction rate of the 1st-step aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene towards 3a and the 3rd-step cyclization (i.e. intramolecular ammonolysis) of 3b were much faster than the 2nd-step methoxycarbonylation of 3a towards 3b with indication of the individual curve slopes. Hence, in this one-pot three-step tandem reaction, the 2nd-step methoxycarbonylation was the rate-determining step for the overall sequence. The following control experiments further confirmed that, with L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 system, the formation of 3ab from phenylacetylene, CO and cyclohexylamine was indeed aided by MeOH-involved methoxycarbonylation (Scheme 2 ). Firstly, 3a was prepared an isolated on purpose according to the rection in Entry 5 of Table 1. And 3b as prepared an isolated on purpose according to the rection in Entry 10 of Table 1. As indicated in eq. 1, even with much excess of cyclohexylamine (2 equiv. to alkyne), the bis-aminocarbonylated product of 3c was not formed at all. And if the secondary amine of diethyl amine was used instead of primary amine of cyclohexylamine, only the ω-amine ester of 4b was formed in 76 %, but without any formation of the di-amide of 4c (eq. 2). These results indicated that, with coexistence of the amine (regardless of whether a primary or secondary one) and MeOH, L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system was orientated to firstly catalyze aminocarbonaltion of the alkyne towards the α,β-unsaturated amide (3a or 4a) and then catalyze methoxycarbonylation of the α,β-unsaturated amide towards the ω-amido ester (3b or 4b) in accurate order without mutual interference, and the bis-aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene with two molecule amine to produce a di-amide product was prohibited. As shown in eq. 3 and 4, when applying the isolated 3a as the starting material, 3a could react with CO and MeOH smoothly to afford 3b (yield: 18 %) and 3ab (yield: 73 %), whereas the reaction of 3a with CO and cyclohexylamine in MeCN failed to produce 3ab, further convincing that, with L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system, the aminocarbonylation of 3a towards 3c was forbidden but the methoxycarbonylation of 3a towards 3b happened smoothly. And the subsequent cyclization of 3b afforded 3ab along with the release of MeOH. When the isolated ω-amide ester of 3b was treated with the same L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system in MeOH under CO atmosphere, 3ab was achieved in 92 % yield (eq. 5). However, without the presence of L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system, no 3ab was found under the same conditions (eq. 6). Thees control experiments further confirmed the studied reaction of phenylacetylene with CO and cyclohexylamine for the synthesis of 3ab was proceeded via aminocarbonylation-methoxycarbonylation-cyclization (intramolecular ammonolysis) tandem sequence. In this three-step tandem reaction, the catalytic system of L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 was not only effective and indispensable for the related carbonylations but also was necessarily required for the 3rd-step cyclization. With L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system, the 1st-step aminocarbonylation of phenylacetylene with cyclohexylamine selectively occurred to produce the branched 3a with 100 % regio-selectivity. The 2nd-step methoxycarbonylation of 3a towards 3b was a decent detour to guarantee this successful sequence for production of 3ab. Based on the afore-mentioned experimental results, we proposed a catalytic mechanism for this tandem reaction catalyzed by L1-based Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 system (Scheme 3 ), wherein the built-in-pyrazinyl-ring as well as the PNP-unit in L1 must play an important role. In this three-step tandem reaction, since the acid-additive of PTSA⋅H2O is required necessarily, the related carbonylation must abide by a widely accepted palladium-hydride (PdII-H) mechanism. Initially, with the aid of PTSA H2O-additive, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2-precursor is complexed with L1 to afford the Pd-H active intermediate of A. As for L1, due to the narrowly confined two-PPh2-fragment in each of PNP-unit, only the development of cis-chelated Pd-complex intermediate with stabilized six-member-ring-structure is permitted as observed by Lang [54]. In this way, the small-size Cl-ion is more favorable than the steric-bulky counter-anion (like OAc or I-) to guarantee the stability of the square-planar Pd-intermediates, accounting for the better performance of Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 than that of Pd(OAc)2 or PdI2. Due to the small-size of Cl--ion as well as the stabilization of η 3-benzyl-coordination to Pd-center (if R1 is aryl group), only the addition of C≡C triple-bond with the Pd-H bond of A following the Markovnikov’s rule is allowed, leading to the absolute formation of the branched alkenyl-palladium intermediate B. Subsequently, the ligand-exchange between Cl- and CO results in the formation of intermediate C. Then CO-migration/insertion in C affords the acyl-palladium intermediate of D, which is attacked by amine rather than MeOH to yield the branched α,β-unsaturated amide (P1) as the more thermodynamically favored product, along with the regeneration of the Pd-H active intermediate of A. In the next catalytic cycle, the gem-positioned C=C double bond in P1 is added with the Pd-H bond of A, affording the alkyl-palladium intermediate of E. The subsequent Cl-/CO-ligand-exchange and CO-migration/insertion leads to the formation of acyl-palladium intermediate of G. In this intermediate G, due to the strong alkaline environment around Pd-periphery coming from the pyrazinyl-linked PNP-unit and the tailed amido-group, the basic amine is repelled out of the Pd-sphere. Naturally, MeOH against amine attacks G to afford P2 (ω-amido ester) for ammonolysis, which is synergetically enhanced by the hydrogen-bond interaction between MeOH and PNP-unit in L1. Finally, upon catalysis also by L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 system, P2 was subjected to intramolecular ammonolysis for cyclization to produce the target N-substituted succinimide of P3. To demonstrate the generality of L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 system for this tandem reaction, a range of substrates including alkynes and amines were selected as listed in Table 2 . When the aliphatic amines (2c-2j) were applied respectively instead of cyclohexylamine to react with phenylacetylene and CO in MeOH, the corresponding N-substituted succinimides (3ac-3ai) were obtained in moderate to good isolated yields (54–82 %). Reasonably, the enhanced steric hindrance in isopropylamine dramatically decelerated the reaction rate, giving the lower yield of 54 % for 3af. When the secondary amine of Et2NH was used to repeat the reaction, only the ω-amido ester of 3aj was obtained in yield of 76 % in consistence to the convinced reaction pathway. However, when the primary aryl amines were introduced to repeat the reaction, the target succinimides (3ak-3am) were obtained in quite low yields (32 ∼ 36 %), accompanied with the branched α,β-unsaturated amides as the major products, which means the 2nd-step methoxycarbonylation is dramatically depressed. As for the different aryl acetylene substrates, it was found that the alkynes with electron-donating group at phenyl ring (1a-1e) could convert to the corresponding succinimides in good yields (65 %-84 %), whereas the alkynes with electron-withdrawing group of meta-F at phenyl ring (1f) just led to the lower yield of 3fb (47 %). However, the alkynes with ortho-/para-Cl at phenyl ring (1g and 1h) were not applicable to this protocol, and only the branched α,β-unsaturated amides (3gb and 3hb) were obtained (81 ∼ 85 %). Reasonably, in the formed 3gb and 3hb, the intensive electron-withdrawing effect from Cl-atom at ortho-/para-position of phenyl ring made the conjugated gem-positioned carbon–carbon double bond too inactive (electron-deficient) to be activated by the Pd-catalyst to take on the continuous reactions. In addition, as for the aliphatic alkyne like 1-hexyne, the corresponding N-cyclohexyl-substituted succinimide (3ib) was given in 66 % GC yield. The investigation on the substrate scope indicated that, the reduced electron-density at the gem-positioned C=C double bond in the α,β-unsaturated amides (by applying primary aryl amines or introducing electron-withdrawing Cl-group at ortho-/para-position of phenyl ring of aryl acetylenes) was unfavorable to the subsequent methoxycarbonylation. 3 Conclusions The new ligands of L1-L3 featured with bis-PNP-units were synthesized by a green synthesis approach without using oxygen/air-sensitive and dangerous BuLi as well as the transition metal catalyst. Therein, L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system exhibited the highest activity, excellent chem-/regio-selectivity, and wide substrate versatility for one-pot tandem reaction of alkynes with CO and two kinds of co-existed nucleophiles (the primary amine and MeOH), affording N-substituted succinimides in moderate to excellent isolated yields. It was found that this tandem reaction was a three-step sequence including aminocarbonylation, methoxycarbonylation and intramolecular ammonolysis, in which MeOH-involved methoxycarbonylation to generate the intermediate product, ω-amino ester, was the decent detour for this overall tandem reaction. The developed L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalytic system proved divergently efficient for each of the individual steps in this three-step tandem sequence, which was a new one-pot synthesis protocol for N-substituted succinimides taking advantage of two types of carbonylation. 4 Experimental Section 4.1 Reagents and analysis The chemical reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Solvents were dried and distilled before use. The 1H/13C/19F NMR and 31P NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer under ambient temperature conditions. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed on an Agilent 6890 equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). GC-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) which equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) was recorded on an Agilent 6890 instrument equipped with an Agilent 5973 mass selective detector. The TG/DTG analysis was determined with a Mettler Toledo TG/DTG 851e thermal analyzer from 25 ℃ to 800 ℃ with a ramp rate of 10 ℃/min. 4.2 Synthesis L1-L4 was synthesized according to the principle of Mannich condensation reaction (Scheme 4 ). L1-L3 were prepared successfully via two-step Mannich condensation using diamines, formaldehyde and HPPh2 as the starting materials. However, in contrast to L2, L4 without the second incorporation of CH2PPh2-fragement at N-site was obtained only via one-step Mannich condensation due to the intensive super-p-π-conjugated effect from pyrazinyl-centred moiety and then the too weak nucleophicity at NH-site to ensue the second-step Mannich condensation. These ligands were synthesized according to the procedures reported in the literature [57] with some modifications. It should be noted that all these ligands (L1-L4) couldn’t be isolated by column chromatography because they were too adsorbed onto silica gel to be eluted. 4.2.1 Synthesis of L1 In N2 atmosphere, a mixture of HPPh2 (6.96 mL, 40 mmol), paraformaldehyde (2.41 g, 80 mmol), and pyrazine-2,5-dianiline (1.1 g, 10 mmol) in toluene (50 mL) was refluxed for 2 h. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was cooled to RT and extracted with CH2Cl2/H2O. The organic phases were collected, dried with magnesium sulfate, and concentrated under vacuum. Then dichloromethane was added to dissolve the resultant viscous solids. The obtained solution was added with anhydrous ethanol for recrystallization. Upon standing for 2–5 h at −20 °C, the yellow microcrystal solids as L1 (5.20 g, 7.9 mmol, 79 % yield) were collected after filtration, washing by anhydrous ethanol and dryness in vacuum at 60 °C. 1H NMR (501 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.70 (s, 2H), 7.36–7.39 (m, 16H), 7.31–7.33 (m, 24H), 4.16 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 8H). 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −24.36. 13C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 146.62, 137.52 (dt, J1 = 3.5 Hz, J2 = 7.4 Hz),133.37 (td, J1 = 1.3 Hz, J2 = 20.2 Hz), 128.89, 128.60(t, J = 3.2 Hz), 51.53 (q, J = 7.2 Hz). Then, according the similar procedures as described for the synthesis of L1, L2 was prepared by replacing the starting material of pyrazine-2,5-diamine with [1,1′:4′,1′'-terphenyl]-2,2′'-diamine. L2 was obtained as a white solid by recrystallization in CH2Cl2/EtOH at −20 °C (7.89 g, 7.5 mmol, 75 % yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.58 (s, 4H), 7.47 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 4H), 7.35 (m, 40H), 6.86 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 4H), 3.98 (d, J = 4.5 Hz, 8H). 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −27.75. 13C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 147.20, 138.88, 137.52, 137.50, 137.46 (dt, J1 = 3.8 Hz, J2 = 14.9 Hz), 137.41, 137.38, 137.35, 133.38 (dt, J1 = 2.4 Hz, J2 = 12.0 Hz), 131.37 (d, J = 8.8 Hz), 129.02, 128.68 (t, J = 3.2 Hz), 127.51, 126.60, 114.69, 54.08 (d, J = 10.1 Hz). CHN-elemental analysis of L4 (C42H36N4P2, found, %): C 76.81, H 5.64, N 8.56 (calcd., C 76.58, H 5.51, N 8.51). 4.3 Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography The intensity data for L2 and L4 were collected on a Bruker SMARTAPEX II diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reduction included absorption corrections by the multiscan method. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares using SHELXS-97 (Sheldrick, 1990), with all nonhydrogen atoms refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added at their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. The crystal data and refinement details were given in Table S2. 4.4 General procedures for the tandem bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes In a typical experiment, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 (25.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), L2 (90.2 mg, 0.1 mmol, or the other ligand), and PTSA H2O (95.1 mg, 0.5 mmol, or the other acid) were mixed with phenylacetylene (5.0 mmol, or the other alkyne), cyclohexylamine (6.0 mmol, or the other amine) and methanol (3 mL). The mixture was added in a 50 mL sealed Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was pressured with CO. Then, the resultant mixture was stirred vigorously at the appointed conditions. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and slowly depressurized. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was diluted with dichloromethane for GC analysis to determine the conversion of phenylacetylene and yield of 1a (n-dodecane as the internal standard) and the product distribution (normalization method). And the products were further identified by GC-mass spectrometry. The obtained products were further identified by 1H/13C NMR spectra (provided in Fig. S6-S24 of SI). coredata.dc:description: A series of base-built-in-PNP-ligands (L1-L4) were synthesized and fully characterized. The synthesis methodology for these ligands were simple and efficient without involvement of high-risky BuLi or high-cost transition metal catalysts. With the aid of the pyrazinyl-tertiary amine-based bis-PNP ligand of L1, in the coexistence of the nucleophiles of amine and MeOH, the terminal alkynes smoothly converted to N-substituted succinimides in moderate to excellent isolated yields, via one-pot three-step tandem reaction in aminocarbonylation-methoxycarbnylation-cyclization sequence. The developed L1-Pd(MeCN)2Cl2 catalyst exhibited typical cascade catalysis with divergent performance towards each individual reaction-step. And the second-step methoxycarbonylation of the branched α,β-unsaturated amides towards ω-amido esters was a decent detour for the successful production of N-substituted succinimides from alkynes, CO and primary amines.
